hint.text:
Given first term and common difference, use the general \(n^{th}\) term equation of A.P.
\(a_n=a+(n-1)d\)

solution.text:
General \(n^{th}\) term of an A.P.
\(a_n=a+(n-1)d\)
Given
a=13 , d=11 and n=16
substitution values into \(n^{th}\) term equation
\(a_ 16=13+(16-1)11\)
\(a_ 16=13 +(15)11\)
\(a_ 16=178\)

content.text: Find the 16\(^{th}\) term of an A.P. whose first term and common difference are 13 and 11 ,respectively

hint.text:
Compare the given \(n^{th}\) term equation with the general \(n^{th}\) term equation of A.P. is
\(a_n=a+(n-1)d\)

solution.text:
\(n^{th}\) term of an A.P. is
\(a_n=a+(n-1)d\)
\(a_n=(a-d)+nd\) ....(1)
where \(a\) =first term and \(d\) =common difference of the A.P.
given that
\( a_n= (-4) +7n\) ....(2)
Comparing equation (1) and (2)
d=7 (from the coefficient of n)
\(a-d=(-4)\) (from the constants)
\(a=(-4)+d\)
\(a=(-4)+7\)
\(a=3\)

content.text: Find the sum of the first term and the common difference of the A.P whose \(n^{th}\) term is \( a_n= (-4) +7n\)

hint.text:
Use \(n^{th}\) term equation of A.P. is
\(a_n=a+(n-1)d\)
to find the a and d from given terms and then use them to find \(n^{th}\) term

solution.text:
a=55
\(n^{th}\) term of an A.P. is
\(a_n=a+(n-1)d\)
\(a_2=a+(2-1)d=54\)
\(a+d=54\)
\(d=54-a=54-55=(-1)\)
i.e. \(a=55\) and \(d=(-1)\) , using them in nth term equation
\(a_n=55+(n-1)(-1)\)
therefore
\(a_ {8}=55+(8-1)(-1)\)
\(a_ {8}=55+(7)(-1)\)
\(a_ {8}=48\)

content.text: Find the sum of the \(8^{th}\) term the A.P. \(55 , 54 , 53 , \ldots \)

hint.text:
Arithmetic mean (A) is a number between two numbers a and b such that the sequence formed a,A,b will be in A.P.
i.e. common difference (d)=A-a=b-A

solution.text:
As mentioned in Hint
Inserting A.M.(A) between two numbers a and b will make the newly formed sequence \(a,A,b\) in A.P.
therefore
the common difference of the A.P. will be
\(d=A-a=b-A\)
\(A-a=b-A\)
\(2A=b+a\)
\(A=\frac{a+b}{2}\)
\(A=24\)

content.text: Find the arithmetic mean (A.M.) of the numbers (-33) and 82?

hint.text: Consider_{q}_ as the first term and _{r}_ as the (_{p}_+2)\(^{th}\) term. Round the answer to 3 decimal places.

solution.text:
To find the common difference between two numbers \(a\) and \(b\) so as to insert \(m\) numbers between them to form an A.P. use the below formula
common difference \(d= \frac{b-a}{m+1}\)

content.text: Find the common difference of th A.P. formed if you insert 3 numbers between (-10) and 23 ?

solution.text:
Sum of any AP will be \( S_n=\frac{n}{2}\times(2a_1+(n-1)\times d)\)
\( S_n=\frac{n}{2}\times(a_1+(a_1+(n-1)\times d))\)
\( S_n=\frac{n}{2}\times(a_1+a_n)\)
here \(a_1=39\) and \(a_n=1039\)
Since both are odd numbers
n=\( \frac{a_n-a_1}{2} +1\)
Thus\( S_n=\frac{a_n-a_1 +2}{4}\times(a_1+a_n)\)

content.text: Find the sum of odd integers from 39 to 1039.

solution.text:
Common difference of the A.P. is
\(d= a_2 - a_1 =a_3 - a_2= (-4)\)
if Sum of n terms is \(S_n\)
\(S_n=\frac{n}{2}\times (2a_1+(n-1)\times d)\)
Manipulating this equation we get
\(n^2d+(2a_1-d)n-2S_n=0\)
Solving this quadratic equation we get n = 7

content.text: How many terms of the A.P.\( (-10) , (-14) , (-18) , . . \) are needed to give the sum (-154)

solution.text:
Let
\(a_a\) = first term of first A.P
\(b_a\) = Common difference of first A.P
\(a_b\) = first term of Second A.P
\(d_b\) = Common difference of second A.P
Let Sum of both A.P. s be \(S_a\) and \(S_b\) respectively, then
\(S_a:S_b=2a_a+(n-1)d_a:2a_b+(n-1)d_b\)
Ratio of \(n^{th}\) terms of two A.P.s will be
\(A_a:A_b= a_a+(n^l-1)d_a:a_b+(n^l-1)d_b\)
Where \(n^l\) is given in the question = 9
Multiplying denominator and numerator with 2
\(A_a:A_b= 2a_a+(2n^l-2)d_a:2a_b+(2n^l-2)d_b\)
also given
\(S_a:S_b=2a_a+(n-1)d_a:2a_b+(n-1)d_b=15n+12 : 6n+4\)
Equating above ratios \(A_a^l:A_b^l=S_a:S_b\) we get n
\(2n^l-2=n-1\)
Solving above equation
\(n=2n^l-1=17\)
Substituting the value of n into the ratio of sums to get the final answer
\(A_a:A_b=\frac{267}{106}\)

content.text: The sum of n terms of two A.P. are in the ratio \(15n+12 : 6n+4\). Find the ratio of their \(9^{th}\) term.

hint.text: Substitute and solve nth term for n= 1,2,3,4,5

solution.text:
Substitute and solve nth term for n= 1,2,3,4,5
\(a_1=1\times (1+20)=21\)
\(a_2=2\times (2+20)=44\)
\(a_3=3\times (3+20)=69\)
\(a_4=4\times (4+20)=96\)
\(a_5=5\times (5+20)=125\)

content.text: Find first five terms of the sequence whose n^th term is \( a_n= (-1)^{n-1} \times 1^{n+1})\)
Find \(17^{th}\) term in the sequence whose \(n^{th}\) term is \( a_n= 8n-17\)

solution.text:
Substitute and solve \(n^{th}\) term for n=7.
\(a_7=\frac{ 10^5}{2^5}=3125 \)

content.text: Find \(10^{th}\) term in the sequence whose \(n^{th}\) term is \( a_n= \frac{ n^5}{2^5}\)

solution.text: Consider each second's velocity as the terms of a sequence. Then \(a_1 = 17 \) at 0 sec , \( a_2=27 \) at 1 sec and \( a_3=37\) at 2 sec. The deference between each term is \( a_2 - a_1 = a_3-a_2=10 \). Therefore \( a_4= a_3 + 10= 47 \) at 3 sec , \( a_5=a_4 + 10 = 57 \) at 4 sec.

content.text: Imagine you threw a coin to the wishing well at a velocity of 17 m/s. If the coin's velocity after first and second seconds are 27 m/s and 37 m/s respectively, what will the speed of coin be after 4 seconds (Assume its a free fall).

solution.text:
The first Installment of INR 60 can be considered as the first term of the A.P. \(a_1 = 60\)
Increment in the installment is the common difference \(d=14\)
n=16
The answer could be found using \(n^{th}\) formula
\(a_n=a_1+(n-1)\times d\)

content.text: A man starts repaying a loan as first installment of INR 60 . If he increases the installment by INR 14 every month, what amount will he pay in the \(16 ^{th}\) installment?

hint.text:
Total interior angle of a polygon is
\((n-2)\times 180\)

solution.text:
Consider the smallest angle 50\(^o\) as first term (\(a_1\)) and the difference between two consecutive interior angles \(16 ^o\) as common difference (\(d\)) of an A.P. .
Let \(n\) = number of sides.
then
Equate total interior angle formula of a polygon with total sum of the A.P.
i.e.
\((n-2)\times 180= \frac{n}{2}\times(2a_1+(n-1)d)\)
Solving this equation you will get
\(n=14\).

content.text: The difference between any two consecutive interior angles of a polygon is \(16 ^o\). If the smallest angle is 50\(^o\) find the number of sides of the polygon.
